slides.title: Introduction to Time and Distance
slides.content:
Time and Distance is a crucial topic in SSC MTS exam that deals with the relationship between the distance traveled, the time taken, and the speed of travel. This concept applies to various real-life scenarios like vehicles traveling, people walking, trains passing platforms, boats moving in rivers, etc.

Understanding Time and Distance helps you solve problems related to journeys, relative speed, average speed, and more. These questions are very common in competitive exams and are usually straightforward if you understand the basic formulas and concepts.

In this chapter, we will cover Speed-Distance-Time relationship, Average Speed, Relative Speed, Problems on Trains, Boats and Streams, and various tricks to solve questions quickly. Mastering these concepts will help you score well in the numerical ability section of SSC MTS.

slides.title: Basic Formula: Speed, Distance, Time
slides.content:
The fundamental relationship between Speed, Distance, and Time is:

Speed = Distance / Time
Distance = Speed × Time
Time = Distance / Speed

Remember this triangle:
       D
      / \
     S × T

Where D = Distance, S = Speed, T = Time

Units:
- Distance: kilometers (km), meters (m)
- Time: hours (h), minutes (min), seconds (sec)
- Speed: km/h, m/s

Unit Conversions (Very Important!):
- To convert km/h to m/s: multiply by 5/18
- To convert m/s to km/h: multiply by 18/5

Example: 36 km/h = 36 × (5/18) = 10 m/s
Example: 15 m/s = 15 × (18/5) = 54 km/h

Basic Examples:
1. A car travels 180 km in 3 hours. Speed = 180/3 = 60 km/h
2. A train runs at 90 km/h for 2 hours. Distance = 90 × 2 = 180 km
3. A bus covers 240 km at 60 km/h. Time = 240/60 = 4 hours

question.questionText: A car travels 150 km in 3 hours. What is its speed in km/h?

slides.title: Average Speed
slides.content:
Average Speed is the total distance traveled divided by total time taken. It is NOT the simple average of speeds!

Formula: Average Speed = Total Distance / Total Time

Case 1: Different distances at different speeds
Average Speed = (D₁ + D₂) / (T₁ + T₂)
Where T₁ = D₁/S₁ and T₂ = D₂/S₂

Case 2: Equal distances at different speeds
If a person travels distance D at speed S₁ and returns the same distance at speed S₂:
Average Speed = 2S₁S₂ / (S₁ + S₂)

This is the Harmonic Mean formula - very important!

Example: A person goes from A to B at 60 km/h and returns at 40 km/h. Find average speed.
Average Speed = (2 × 60 × 40) / (60 + 40) = 4800 / 100 = 48 km/h
Note: It's NOT (60+40)/2 = 50 km/h!

Case 3: Equal time at different speeds
Average Speed = (S₁ + S₂) / 2 (Simple arithmetic mean)

Example: A person travels for 2 hours at 30 km/h and 2 hours at 50 km/h.
Average Speed = (30 + 50) / 2 = 40 km/h

question.questionText: A person travels from A to B at 40 km/h and returns from B to A at 60 km/h. What is the average speed?
question.explanation: For equal distances: Average Speed = (2 × 40 × 60) / (40 + 60) = 4800 / 100 = 48 km/h.

slides.title: Relative Speed
slides.content:
Relative Speed is the speed at which two objects are moving relative to each other.

Case 1: Objects moving in SAME direction
Relative Speed = |S₁ - S₂| (Difference of speeds)
They appear to be moving slower relative to each other.

Example: Train A (60 km/h) and Train B (40 km/h) moving in same direction.
Relative Speed = 60 - 40 = 20 km/h

Case 2: Objects moving in OPPOSITE directions
Relative Speed = S₁ + S₂ (Sum of speeds)
They appear to be moving faster relative to each other.

Example: Car A (50 km/h) and Car B (30 km/h) moving towards each other.
Relative Speed = 50 + 30 = 80 km/h

Applications:
- When two trains cross each other
- When one train overtakes another
- When two people meet while walking

Example: Two trains 100m and 150m long are running at 45 km/h and 36 km/h in opposite directions. Time to cross = ?
Total distance = 100 + 150 = 250 m
Relative speed = 45 + 36 = 81 km/h = 81 × (5/18) = 22.5 m/s
Time = 250 / 22.5 = 11.11 seconds

slides.title: Problems on Trains - Part 1
slides.content:
Train problems are very common in SSC MTS exams. Key concept: When a train crosses a stationary object, it has to travel its own length.

Case 1: Train crossing a pole/man/post
Time = Length of Train / Speed of Train

Example: A 150m long train crosses a pole in 15 seconds. Find speed.
Speed = 150 / 15 = 10 m/s = 10 × (18/5) = 36 km/h

Case 2: Train crossing a platform/bridge
Time = (Length of Train + Length of Platform) / Speed

Example: A 200m train crosses a 300m platform in 25 seconds. Find speed.
Total distance = 200 + 300 = 500m
Speed = 500 / 25 = 20 m/s = 72 km/h

Case 3: Train crossing another stationary train
Time = (Length of Train 1 + Length of Train 2) / Speed of Train 1

Example: A 150m train passes a 100m stationary train in 10 seconds.
Speed = (150 + 100) / 10 = 25 m/s = 90 km/h

question.questionText: A train 120m long crosses a pole in 12 seconds. What is its speed in km/h?

slides.title: Problems on Trains - Part 2
slides.content:
Case 4: Two trains moving in SAME direction
Time to cross = (L₁ + L₂) / (S₁ - S₂)
Where L = Length, S = Speed, and S₁ > S₂

Example: Train A (150m, 72 km/h) overtakes Train B (100m, 54 km/h).
Relative speed = 72 - 54 = 18 km/h = 5 m/s
Time = (150 + 100) / 5 = 50 seconds

Case 5: Two trains moving in OPPOSITE directions
Time to cross = (L₁ + L₂) / (S₁ + S₂)

Example: Train A (120m, 60 km/h) and Train B (180m, 48 km/h) approach each other.
Relative speed = 60 + 48 = 108 km/h = 30 m/s
Time = (120 + 180) / 30 = 10 seconds

Trick: In train problems:
- Same direction: Subtract speeds
- Opposite direction: Add speeds
- Always add lengths of both trains
- Convert km/h to m/s when lengths are in meters

slides.title: Boats and Streams
slides.content:
Boats and Streams problems involve a boat traveling in a river with a current. The current either helps or opposes the boat's motion.

Key Terms:
- Speed of Boat in Still Water (b): Speed when no current
- Speed of Stream/Current (s): Speed of water flow
- Downstream: Boat moving WITH the current (current helps)
- Upstream: Boat moving AGAINST the current (current opposes)

Formulas:
Downstream Speed = b + s
Upstream Speed = b - s

From these:
Speed in Still Water (b) = (Downstream + Upstream) / 2
Speed of Stream (s) = (Downstream - Upstream) / 2

Example: Downstream speed = 15 km/h, Upstream speed = 9 km/h
Speed in still water = (15 + 9) / 2 = 12 km/h
Speed of stream = (15 - 9) / 2 = 3 km/h

Time and Distance:
Time to travel distance D downstream = D / (b + s)
Time to travel distance D upstream = D / (b - s)

question.questionText: A boat travels downstream at 18 km/h and upstream at 12 km/h. What is the speed of the boat in still water?
question.explanation: Speed in still water = (Downstream + Upstream) / 2 = (18 + 12) / 2 = 30 / 2 = 15 km/h.

slides.title: Meeting Point and Crossing Problems
slides.content:
When two people/vehicles start from different points and move towards each other:

Meeting Time = Total Distance / (S₁ + S₂)
Meeting Point from first starting point = S₁ × Meeting Time

Example: A and B are 120 km apart. A travels at 30 km/h and B at 20 km/h towards each other.
Meeting time = 120 / (30 + 20) = 120 / 50 = 2.4 hours
Meeting point from A = 30 × 2.4 = 72 km

Circular Track:
When two people run on a circular track:

Same direction: Time to meet again = Circumference / |S₁ - S₂|
Opposite direction: Time to meet = Circumference / (S₁ + S₂)

Example: Two runners on a 400m track, speeds 8 m/s and 6 m/s
Same direction: 400 / (8-6) = 200 seconds
Opposite direction: 400 / (8+6) = 28.57 seconds

Chasing Problems:
If A starts first and B chases after time t:
B catches A when: Distance covered by A = Distance covered by B
S₁ × T = S₂ × (T - t)

question.questionText: Two people are 100 km apart and travel towards each other at 30 km/h and 20 km/h. When will they meet?
question.explanation: Meeting time = Total Distance / (S₁ + S₂) = 100 / (30 + 20) = 100 / 50 = 2 hours.

slides.title: Important Tricks and Shortcuts
slides.content:
1. Quick Conversion:
   18 km/h = 5 m/s
   36 km/h = 10 m/s
   54 km/h = 15 m/s
   72 km/h = 20 m/s
   90 km/h = 25 m/s

2. If speed increases by x%, time decreases by [x/(100+x)] × 100%
   If speed decreases by x%, time increases by [x/(100-x)] × 100%

3. If a person covers distances D₁, D₂, D₃ at speeds S₁, S₂, S₃:
   Average Speed = (D₁ + D₂ + D₃) / (D₁/S₁ + D₂/S₂ + D₃/S₃)

4. For three equal parts of journey at speeds S₁, S₂, S₃:
   Average Speed = 3 / (1/S₁ + 1/S₂ + 1/S₃)

5. Time saved = Original Time - New Time

6. Remember: Distance = Speed × Time (write this triangle in exam)

7. Always check units - convert km/h to m/s when dealing with meters

8. In boat problems, downstream is always faster than upstream

Practice is key! Solve as many problems as possible to master Time and Distance for your SSC MTS exam.
